    BuzzFeed Style Guide

    The BuzzFeed Style Guide aims to provide a prevailing, and evolving, set of standards for the internet and social media.

    by BuzzFeed News

    BuzzFeed News

    BuzzFeed publishes news and entertainment in the language of the web, and in our work, we rely on a style guide to govern everything from hard-hitting journalism to fun quizzes. We value consistency and accuracy across those formats and categories. (For instance, knowing how to treat numbers is important, but so is correctly spellingÂ memeable.) Our perspective reflects that of the internet at large, which is why we hope other sites and organizations across the web will find these guidelines useful.

    This style guide is updated regularly to ensure it remains relevant and responds accordingly to changes in language and common, casual usage.

    Tip: Use the Find command (ctrl + F on a PC; âŒ˜ + F on a Mac) to search for specific words or topics.


    BuzzFeedâ€™s preferred dictionary isÂ merriam-webster.com. InÂ MW, the first spelling of a word should generally be used (unless it appears in the word list below or is preferred by theÂ Associated Press Stylebook). Our preferred style manual is theÂ AP Stylebook, which trumpsÂ MW, but any style point mentioned in this guide overrules those publications.

    This style guide provides a reference to common words and terms used on BuzzFeed and information on style issues particular to the site. It is not intended to be a comprehensive manual of grammar and style.

    â€¢ In most cases, do not use an acronym or abbreviation on first reference.
    â€¢ If it is clear and familiar enough in context, no need to put it in parentheses after a spelled-out reference; use your judgment.
    â€¢ Lowercase acronyms with six letters or more, e.g., â€œNasdaqâ€ (exception: NASCAR).

    ableism (see also disability):
    â€¢ Avoid ableist language (discriminating against people with disabilities), including figurative use of words like lame, crutch, or handicap (which historically described physical disabilities) and crazy, stupid, or insane (once used as official diagnoses for people housed in institutions) and idioms like lame duck (opt for outgoing president), turns a blind eye, or falls on deaf ears (use willfully ignorant instead).     â€¢ Use nondisabled or person without a disability rather than able-bodied, which implies that people with disabilities lack â€œable bodies,â€ per NCDJ guidance.
    â€¢ Use low support needs or high support needs when writing about disabled people. Avoid high- and low-functioning; how someone is â€œfunctioningâ€ can change day to day, but support needs do not change so often. Avoid special needs, differently abled, and handicapable.

    corrections:
    â€¢ A correction should include the accurate information. It should explain the error, and it may restate the error when itâ€™s necessary to clarify what it was or to debunk a claim. See sample corrections at the end of this section.
    â€¢ Corrections should be made for errors of fact â€” not misspellings, typos, or broken links. DO issue a correction, however, if a person or brandâ€™s name is misspelled throughout a story (even if a name appears only once and is misspelled).
    â€¢ If a correction is issued for a misspelling, it should be stated simply asÂ [TK person]â€™s name was misspelled in an earlier version of this post.
    â€¢ The correctionâ€™s tone should echo the tone of the item, in keeping with its gravity. A basic mistake on a list of weird facts aboutÂ Love ActuallyÂ can begin with â€œGah!â€; a correction of an error of fact in a news story should not.
    â€¢ Corrections should be in plain English, not in the somewhat formal corrections style traditional among news organizations.
    â€¢ Be very thorough and careful. The absolute worst thing is to have to correct your correction. If the correction is about a person, itâ€™s often a good move to read the correction on the phone to its subject before printing it.
    â€¢ Try to mention the correction on all channels the story went out on â€” if you tweeted it, tweet the correction, etc.
    â€¢ Using the â€œcorrectionâ€ option will autoformat and timestamp your correction.
    â€¢ Donâ€™t add a correction without first running the proposed correction by your editor or team leader.
    â€¢ If someone on social media pointed out the error, be generous to that person â€” whether you are feeling generous or not, and no matter how obnoxious the comment. That person did you a favor by improving your piece. On Twitter, if possible, end the correction with â€œ(H/T: @twittercorgi)â€ and a link to the tweet in question. If a hat tip appears in a dek or in the middle of running copy as a stand-alone sentence, use end punctuation.

    correction examples:

    â€¢Â Newsy, restating the error:Â Twitterâ€™s CEO could not be reached for comment. An earlier version of this post said Twitterâ€™s CFO could not be reached for comment.Â (This is also an example of when what was maybe just a typo warrants a correction rather than just a quick fix.)
    â€¢Â Newsy, where BuzzFeed reported what was correct at the time but was later found to be incorrect:Â An earlier version of this article, using information provided by the Las Cruces Police Department, misstated Battistaâ€™s charges. He is charged with breaking and entering.
    â€¢Â Humorous, simple correction:Â Gah! Miley was first documented twerking in public on Jan. 20, 2013. An earlier version of this post had the wrong date.
    â€¢Â Humorous, restating the error:Â Oops! Samantha moved to London in theÂ Sex and the CityÂ revival. An earlier version of this post said she died. RIP our mentions!

    hyphens:
    â€¢ Do NOT use a hyphen after an adverb (not limited to but including most words ending in â€œ-lyâ€), e.g., â€œIt was a poorly written book,â€ notÂ poorly-written.

    â€¢ Slashes are OK in specific contexts (like â€œand/orâ€), but use hyphens for basic compounds and double titles like â€œsinger-songwriterâ€ (notÂ singer/songwriter) or â€œwriter-director.â€
    â€¢ When a modifying phrase is longer than a couple of words, quotation marks can sometimes be easier to read than a ton of hyphens, e.g., â€œHe heaved a â€˜back to the drawing boardâ€™ sigh.â€ Use quotes rather than hyphens in a modifying phrase that would be said aloud, e.g., â€œa â€˜press 1 for Englishâ€™ call,â€ â€œa â€˜shit is getting realâ€™ afternoon.â€

    â€¢ AÂ majorityÂ is more than half the votes cast; aÂ pluralityÂ is the largest number of votes, but less than a majority; aÂ supermajorityÂ is any institutionally defined threshold greater than a simple majority.

    Transgender TermsÂ (some of these are adapted from theÂ GLAAD Transgender Glossary of Terms)
    â€¢Â Transgender: An umbrella term (always an adjective, never a noun) for people whose gender identity and/or gender expression differs from what is typically associated with the sex they were assigned at birth.     â€¢Â Transsexual: An older term (NOT an umbrella term), which originated in the medical and psychological communities. Use as an adjective and only if preferred by an individual.
    â€¢Â Cross-dressing: Occasionally wearing clothes traditionally associated with people of another sex. â€œCross-dresserâ€ should NOT be used to describe someone who has transitioned to live full-time as a gender other than the one assigned to them at birth or who intends to do so in the future.

    people-first language    : People-first language refers to descriptions that center the individual(s) rather than the condition(s) â€” for example, using â€œperson with a disabilityâ€ instead of â€œdisabled person.â€ Although PFL was created by disability advocates to emphasize the agency of disabled people, it has fallen out of favor in certain communities.
